message: A 29-year-old woman was admitted to the hospital because of sore throat and peritonsillar swelling and bleeding. Symptoms did not abate with antimicrobial therapy.
Could you describe in detail how and when your sore throat and peritonsillar swelling began, including any associated bleeding episodes, pain severity, and whether symptoms have changed over time?

She reported that approximately 7 weeks before admission she first noted a mild sore throat, which persisted despite rest and fluids and did not improve with azithromycin. Over the next days the pain worsened, interfering with sleep, and she developed right-sided throat swelling and a sensation of food sticking when swallowing. Thirty-one days before admission, drainage yielded only sanguineous fluid without purulence. Despite amoxicillin–clavulanate, symptoms waxed and waned; 2 weeks before admission pain and swelling decreased, but 8 days before admission she noted a “froggy” voice and intermittent bleeding. Four days before admission, aspiration yielded dark blood. On the morning of admission, she awoke with increased pain and swelling, felt a “pop,” and noted active bleeding, prompting evaluation.
Have you experienced fevers, night sweats, unintentional weight loss, fatigue, or any other systemic symptoms during these seven weeks?
The patient reported fatigue but denied fevers, night sweats, or unintentional weight loss. She noted easy bruising and heavy menstrual bleeding.
